SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating. He attributes this to the change in seasons and recent home construction projects. These symptoms have been present for about five weeks. The patient has been adhering to his medications but has struggled with his diet due to kitchen renovations and eating out more frequently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fever, chills. Positive fatigue and lightheadedness.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses bloating. No chest pain.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath during exertion. Slight cough.
• Gastrointestinal: No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Vital signs within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Ejection fraction of 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam findings and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Patient to weigh themselves daily and report any weight gain or worsening symptoms. Order a follow-up echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Patient to continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevations via the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was trying to change a light bulb on a ladder yesterday and stumbled, twisting her knee as she tried to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial portion of the knee over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with flexion and valgus stressing of the leg. Normal sensation in the lower extremity. No calf pain.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the left knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but overall alignment is normal.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for re-evaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a 2-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he felt a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved. He has been experiencing stiffness since then. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat without significant relief. He felt some tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, he admits to having a sweet tooth and not having the best diet recently. He is currently on metformin.

Regarding his hypertension, he monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends. He is taking his medication as prescribed.

Regarding his osteoarthritis, he experiences occasional aggravation, especially when lifting heavy objects or running too much.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Endorses occasional knee pain related to osteoarthritis.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in toes on the right foot, which resolved on Sunday afternoon.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of his back reveals pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Decreased range of motion with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

X-ray lumbar spine, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing the area and avoid strenuous activity.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for strengthening exercises.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: He has been compliant with metformin, but his recent hemoglobin A1c was 8.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are running on the high side.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is monitoring his knee and managing his symptoms.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam, follow-up of depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He has been managing his hypertension with Norvasc, but admits to occasionally forgetting to take it on weekends. The patient had a lobectomy a couple of years ago and reports no significant issues with shortness of breath, except during high pollen season and humid weather.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, reports occasional chest pounding during exercise.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath with exertion.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression, managed with Prozac.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is doing well on Prozac 20 mg daily.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Refill prescription for Prozac.

2. Prior Lobectomy:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient has no significant issues with shortness of breath and exercises regularly.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed at this time.

3. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-controlled with Norvasc.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident over the weekend. She reports her finger was bent back while skiing over moguls.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation
Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and everything lines up well.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for a week. If the pain does not improve, the patient is advised to call and return for a follow-up. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper, a 65-year-old female, presents as a new patient referred by Diane Nelson for long-standing iron deficiency anemia. The patient reports being anemic since the age of 13. She recently attempted to donate blood in December and was informed of her anemia. She has been experiencing fatigue, feverishness, chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, and worsening anxiety and depression. The patient had a hysterectomy in 1996 and her last colonoscopy was 5-6 years ago with no significant findings.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Iron deficiency anemia.
Hysterectomy in 1996.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Alcohol consumption: occasional, once or twice a year.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets, twice daily.
Over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAM

General: Patient appears well-nourished and in no acute distress.
Cardiovascular: Heart sounds normal.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, and non-distended.

ASSESSMENT

Iron deficiency anemia.

PLAN

1. Upper endoscopy and colonoscopy: Schedule these procedures to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.

2. Hematologist referral: Send a referral to Dr. Flores for evaluation and potential intravenous iron treatment or other interventions to improve iron storage.

3. Iron supplementation: Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets twice daily with orange juice for improved absorption. Reassess blood work after 8-12 weeks, including CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate levels.

INSTRUCTIONS

Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy appointments. Follow bowel prep instructions provided. Schedule an appointment with Dr. Flores, the hematologist. Call the clinic with any questions or worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. He was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with worsening headaches over the past few months. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Labs dated 3/3/21, including CBC, UNES, UH, coagulation, and CRP, were all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, and all other results were normal. MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size, and no other abnormalities are noted.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
None

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occupation: Computer programmer
Marital status: Married for 25 years
Alcohol, tobacco, and recreational drug use: None

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None

EXAMINATION

The patient is alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT

• Pituitary adenoma

PLAN

1. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision prior to surgery.
2. Schedule surgery for transsphenoidal approach to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa.
3. Counsel the patient on the risks associated with anesthesia and surgery, including infection, need for further surgery, wound issues, seizure, stroke, permanent numbness, weakness, difficulty speaking, or even death.
4. Monitor the patient's vision post-surgery to assess improvement.
5. Encourage the patient to call if they have any questions or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53 y.o. female who presents today for evaluation of chest pain and difficulty swallowing that occurred in October 2020. The patient reports that she had chest pain for four days, which was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone. The pain was sharp and felt worse with eating. She also experienced difficulty swallowing during this time. The patient sought care at the emergency room, where she had a normal EKG and blood tests. The ER suspected a GI issue and referred her to our clinic. The patient's symptoms resolved three days after her ER visit and have not recurred since then.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Uterine fibroids.
Anemia.
Esophagitis (suspected).

Surgical
Cholecystectomy (gallbladder removal).

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient does not report any significant social history.

FAMILY HISTORY

The patient is not aware of any family history of GI problems.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None reported.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Negative for weight loss, weight gain, abdominal pain, and abnormal bowel movements.
Positive for chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020, which have since resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAM

The patient has mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. The rest of the exam is normal.

ASSESSMENT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020, with possible etiologies including GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal issues, and anxiety. The patient's symptoms have resolved, and it is suspected that she may have had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, with possible contribution from musculoskeletal issues.

PLAN

1. Discussed the option of EGD versus monitoring for symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any recurrence or change.
2. The patient should follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Kidney evaluation for Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for kidney evaluation. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days, weighing 4 pounds, 8 ounces. She has had issues with feeding and regulating her temperature but is currently doing well. Katherine is in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. She has seen a GI doctor, allergist, neurologist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The patient's geneticist mentioned potential kidney issues related to her syndrome.

The patient has approximately 8 to 10 wet diapers in a 24-hour period. She drinks a combination of pea protein milk, water, and diluted juice.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
Premature birth (34 weeks and 3 days).

FAMILY HISTORY

No family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined. Eyes appear small. Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT

Smith-Magenis Syndrome with potential congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.

PLAN

1. Perform a kidney ultrasound today to screen for any abnormalities.
2. If the ultrasound results are normal, no further follow-up with nephrology is needed.
3. If the ultrasound results are abnormal, schedule a follow-up appointment at the Town Center location to discuss next steps and future management.

INSTRUCTIONS

Complete kidney ultrasound today. Await results and follow-up as needed based on the outcome of the ultrasound.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her right arm. She has not had any previous injuries to this arm. The patient rates her pain level as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The injury occurred yesterday morning. The patient reports some tingling in her fingers but is still able to feel them.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Reports tingling in fingers but denies numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: No carotid bruit, no thyromegaly, no adenopathy.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: No lower leg edema, palpable pulses.
MSK: Right wrist with obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Able to make a fist but not tightly. Bony crepitus present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a discussion with the patient regarding her current symptoms and diagnosis. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. We will treat the patient conservatively initially with a brace for her right wrist. I have recommended surgery for the patient, which will be followed by a period of immobilization in a brace for six weeks. I have prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management. The patient will begin physical therapy a few weeks after surgery. We will re-evaluate the patient in a month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to follow up in a month for re-evaluation and to contact the office if her pain does not improve or worsens.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, on 20 mg Lisinopril.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: not provided
Respiration: not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain with flexion and extension. Pain to palpation on the medial aspect. No pain on the lateral aspect. Edema and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. No fractures or bony abnormalities were found.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports slipping and falling, resulting in knee pain and swelling.
- Medical Treatment: Ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Knee brace for support. Ice therapy for 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily to reduce swelling. Elevate and rest the leg.
- Follow-up: Reevaluate in a few weeks.

2. Hypertension
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on 20 mg Lisinopril. Blood pressure was elevated at 150/70 mmHg during the visit.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of diet and sodium intake in managing hypertension.
- Medical Treatment: Continue 20 mg Lisinopril. Referral to nutritionist for dietary guidance.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in a few weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and suspects it might be related. The patient states he is very active and has experienced occasional aches and pains before that usually resolve with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant and worsens with pressure. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that her left knee occasionally gives out while walking, causing her to nearly fall. She describes the pain as internal and involving the whole kneecap. The pain comes and goes quickly, and she denies any history of injury to the knee. The patient has not taken any medications for the pain, as it does not last long. She is concerned about her upcoming trip, which will involve a lot of walking and line dancing, and is unsure if she will be able to participate due to her knee issues.

MEDICATIONS

The patient is currently taking Farxiga, Amlodipine, Lisinopril, Hydrochlorothiazide, and Metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies right knee pain.

Cardiovascular: Reports controlled blood pressure.

Endocrine: Reports slightly elevated morning blood sugars.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.

Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

MSK: Examination of the left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation of the left medial knee. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension, controlled.
3. Diabetes mellitus, with slightly elevated morning blood sugars.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider initiating physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.
2. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order a hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes control and make any necessary adjustments to the Metformin dosage.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She is currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. Biopsy of a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good support from family, friends, and nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports a dry cough and sore throat.
Gastrointestinal: Denies difficulty swallowing or feeling of food getting stuck.
Psychiatric: Reports feeling emotionally and mentally strong.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck
- Examination: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy noted.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side, possibly related to radiation.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema noted.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen of cisplatin and etoposide. Continue current dose of radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of radiation to assess tumor size for potential surgical removal.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation.

3. Sore throat and painful swallowing.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow to be used four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports frequent colds that tend to linger for a long time, especially during the winter season. No recent abdominal infections or diarrhea. Patient was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient recently traveled to Zambia. Patient's family owns a donut shop.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal tenderness.

VITALS

Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LABORATORY RESULTS

Low IgA level.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work is consistent with an IgA deficiency, which is a common immunodeficiency. Most people with this deficiency live normal lives without knowing they have it. Some may experience frequent respiratory, sinus, or abdominal infections, but this does not seem to be the case for the patient.
- Additional Testing: Order blood work to check other antibodies to rule out other immunodeficiencies.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Informed the patient about the IgA deficiency and advised them to watch for infections that do not resolve or any changes in their abdominal tract. Instructed the patient to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.

2. Type 2 diabetes.
- Continue metformin as prescribed by the primary care physician. Encourage moderation in diet and lifestyle.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended assessment and plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. He reports that the pain began about four days ago and is located on the inside of his right elbow. The patient has been engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic, which he believes may have contributed to the pain. The pain is rated as a 6/10 and has been affecting his sleep and daily activities. He has tried ibuprofen for relief with minimal success.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Pulses are equal in all extremities.
NEURO: Sensation is normal to light touch distally.
MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis. The patient is advised to rest the affected elbow and wear a sling while awake. He is instructed to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day and take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for a full week. The patient is also advised to refrain from pottery work for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for one week to evaluate his progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up after a fall and chest pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath.
Genitourinary: Denies urinary incontinence.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting his sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding his diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed dietary modifications as noted above.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and groin. The pain is intermittent and comes in severe episodes. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones (father). He has taken Tylenol for the pain with minimal relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports nausea but no vomiting.
Genitourinary: Reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA: Positive tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Right kidney stone (acute nephrolithiasis).

PLAN

1. Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. Patient may continue to take Tylenol as needed.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to strain urine and monitor for stone passage.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks to assess progress. If symptoms persist, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to contact the clinic if symptoms worsen or if there are any concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for approximately 6 weeks, which started as a blister after wearing tight shoes. He has been experiencing a foul smell, yellow drainage, and the wound has turned black around the edges. He has also been experiencing cramping in his calf muscle and a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle. The patient has been on antibiotics for 6 days and has been experiencing a fever of 99.7°F and chills. He reports his blood sugars have been trending in the 300-400 range for the past two weeks, with one spike at 500-600.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy. His last A1c was 6.7.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports being active and enjoys hiking with his wife. He has been wearing diabetic shoes and inserts.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever and chills.
Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports coughing and difficulty catching breath.
Skin: Patient reports non-healing right foot ulcer with foul smell and yellow drainage.
Neurological: No reported issues.

VITALS

Fever: 99.7°F
Blood pressure: Not provided
Heart rate: Not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Not provided
RESPIRATORY: Not provided
NECK: Not provided
MSK: Examination of the right foot reveals a 2 x 2 cm necrotic wound on the heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. Bilateral femoral and popliteal pulses are palpable, but dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are not palpable (present via Doppler).

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer, right foot
2. Diabetes with recent blood sugar instability
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have discussed the current symptoms and plan with the patient. We will order a test to check blood supply for the wound. Debridement will be performed in the office today, and a culture will be taken. We may need to adjust antibiotic therapy based on the culture results. The patient will continue the current antibiotic course and follow up in 7 days. The patient is advised to follow up with their endocrinologist for diabetes management and to closely monitor blood sugars.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee with associated pain and erythema.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors, including hunting and yard work. He noticed a tick bite on his right knee over a week ago, which has been causing burning pain and annoyance.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, body aches.
Musculoskeletal: Reports arthritic pain, but no new joint pain since tick bite.
Neurological: Reports headache and general malaise since tick bite.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension: Controlled with lisinopril.
Diabetes: Controlled with metformin.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Normal
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion in right knee. Pain to palpation of right anterior knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Suspected Lyme disease due to tick bite and bull's-eye rash.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.

2. Hypertension: Controlled with lisinopril.
- Continue lisinopril 20 mg once daily.
- Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes: Controlled with metformin.
- Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
- Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control.
- Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed and after receiving test results.
